newsitem.title: MEXICO: Cifra results suggest consumer returning.
newsitem.headline: Cifra results suggest consumer returning.

text.p: Second quarter results from Mexican retail giant Cifra, if not spectacular, highlight the trend towards a rebound in domestic consumption, analysts said.
"The consumer recovery has been slow and that has been seen even more so in Cifra due to the geographical zone in which it operates," said Inverlat analyst Deyanira Becerril.
Cifra has a concentration of stores in the Mexican capital, which has been slower to recuperate from the 1994 peso devaluation and subsequent recession than the country's north.
But analysts were encouraged by the one percent growth Cifra registered in same store sales.

"The one percent increase in same store sales is the first postive number reported since the devaluation and I expect positive numbers for the rest of the year," said ING Barings analyst Barry Taylor.
Cifra reported net sales in the second quarter of 6.19 million pesos, above the 5.97 million pesos in the same period last year.
Real growth in sales was 4.0 percent. Taking the inflation differential for the period into account, the increase was one percent.
However analysts say that between April and June the firm's operating margin was 3.8 percent -- slightly below average expectations of 4.5 percent recorded in a Reuter survey of three analysts.
But they said the results were mainly in line with expectations.
Although operating results were weaker than expected, Cifra's financial results were above expectations once interest from extraordinary gains was taken into account.
"The only surprise was that they realised an extraordinary gain, which I was not expecting until the fourth quarter," said Merrill Lynch analyst Robert Ford.

Cifra said that in the second quarter it had liquidated part of its pension plan under plans to merge its subsidiaries with Wal Mart's Mexico stores, giving it a extraordinary gain of 887 million pesos.
Analysts say that its expansion plans should enable it to increase is sales by four or five percent over the next one to two years.
